document.docAuthor: Chavtur, Vladimir G., Keyser, Dietmar & Bashmanov, Alexander G.
document.masterDocTitle: First record and description of male of Metavargula adinothrix Kornicker, 1975 (Ostracoda: Myodocopina) from the Southern Ocean

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First record and description of male of Metavargula adinothrix Kornicker, 1975 (Ostracoda: Myodocopina) from the Southern Ocean

bibRefCitation.author: Kornicker
bibRefCitation.refString: Kornicker, L. S. (1975) Antarctic Ostracoda (Myodocopina). Part 1. Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology, 163, 1 - 374.

subSubSection.paragraph: Material . ZIM-K- 41902 , adult male, length 3.94 mm . Valves in micropalaeontological chamber, some
appendages in alcohol, remaining appendages on slide. R/V “Polarstern”, ANT XXII- 3 , St. 150 – 6 – 5 ,

61 º 49.14 ´S
–
47 º 27.51 ´W
to
61 º 48.53 ´S
–
47 º 28.16 ´W
, depth 1971.0 – 1999.0 m, Epibenthos sledge, 20 March
Additional material . R/V “Polarstern”, ANT XIX- 3

Description of adult male . Carapace ( Figs. 2 , 3 , 4 A). Length 3.95 mm . Greatest height about 55 %. Oval with broadly rounded anterior, small incisur and developed rostrum. Posterior relatively elongate upsweeping caudal siphon with wide quadratic top. Caudal process with infold, broad and covered with tiny pores. List on infold in front of caudal process with pores and minute bristles. Surface of valves smooth but scale-like under high magnification.

First antenna (Figs. 4 B, D; 5 A). 1 st and 2 nd segments bare; 3 rd and 4 th segments each with one ventral and one dorsal bristle; sensory bristle of 5 th segment with 12 long proximal paddle-like and 2 long distal slender bare filaments (each with terminal papilla), bifurcate tip, and about half length of g-bristle and somewhat more than 3 times length of a-bristle. Medial bristle on 6 th segment subequal to length of its dorsal margin and bare. 7 th segment: a-bristle bare and about twice as long as length of bristle on 6 th segment, b-bristle somewhat less than 3 times as long as a-bristle and about 1 / 3 length of g-bristle with 4 filaments (proximal filament stout with bulbous proximal part followed by large sucker and small protuberance; 2 nd and 3 rd filaments near middle of bristle slender each with 2 small discs, 4 th filament also slender but bare) and bifurcate tip; c-bristle (terminally broken) with 10 filaments (proximal filament similar to stout proximal filament of b-bristle but with somewhat less pronounced sucker, followed by 2 slender filaments each with 2 small discs, then bare filaments). 8 th segment: d- and e-bristles somewhat longer than 60 % of b-bristle, bare and with blunt tip; fbristle longer about 1.6 times than b-bristle, with 9 filaments (each with 4-5 spines) and bifurcate tip; g-bristle somewhat longer than f-bristle with 9 filaments (each with 4-5 spines) and bifurcate tip.

Second antenna (Figs. 4 E–H; 5 B,C). Protopodite with short bare medial bristle, subequal to length of exopodite and somewhat longer than its 1 st segment. Endopodite weak, 2 -segmented: 1 st segment with 3 proximal ( 2 short and 1 long) and 1 distal long bristles, 2 nd segment armed with long terminal filament. Exopodite: 1 st segment barely shorter than total 2 nd – 9 th segments; bristle on 2 nd segment with 7 – 10 distal spines on ventral margin (dorsal margin bare), about 70 % length of 1 st segment and 25 % of bristle on 3 rd segment, with bifurcate tip; bristles on 3 rd to 9 th segments with natatory setules and without spines; 9 th segment with 3 long and 1 short bristles; segments 3 rd to 9 th with basal spines; basal spines smaller on proximal segments, but lateral spine on 9 th segment smaller than basal spines of 7 th and 8 th segment.

Mandible (Figs. 5 D–F; 6 A–F). Coxale endite with 2 relatively stout terminal spines and tiny peg between them, short bristle and process present at basale on endite. Basale: dorsal margin with 1 distal and 2 terminal bristles; ventral margin with 1 a- and 1 b-bristles, 2 c-bristles ( 1 short distal and one midlength proximal) and 2 d-bristles ( 1 long distal and other midlength proximal). Exopodite slightly longer than dorsal margin of 1 st endopodite segment, with 2 spinous bristles and pointed tip, dorso-distal part hirsute. Endopodite: ventral margin of 1 st segment with 4 bristles, 2 long ( 1 plumose) and 2 short bare; ventral margin of 2 nd segment with 2–3 groups of bristles having 1, 1 (only 1 on left limb) and 2 bristles, all short (medial bristles of terminal pair broad and with teeth along inner margin); dorsal margin of 2 nd segment with 5 long, 2 medium length and 7–8 short bristles. End segment with 4 claws and 3 bristles ( 1 short, 1 medium length and 1 long).

Maxilla (Figs. 6 G– I; 7 A,B). Coxale with stout, relatively long, plumose bristle. Endite bristles not counted. Exopodite broad, with usual 3 bristles, 2 proximal plumose and 1 distal bare. Endopodite: cutting edge of 1 st segment with 3 teeth, 2 alpha-bristles present (outer bristle longer and plumose, inner bristle bare) and 3 beta-bristles ( 2 short and 1 long, all with long spines along inner margin); 2 nd segment with 3–4 a-, 3 b-, 1–2 c- and 1–2 d-bristles.

Fifth limb (Figs. 7 C–E; 8 A–C). Epipodial appendage deformed. Anterio-distal process of protopodite small and curved. Endite bristles not counted. Endopodite: main tooth of 1 st segment consisting of usual 5 pectinate teeth and peg with proximal posterior bristle; 2 nd segment with smooth anterior bristle and 15 bristles on margin adjacent to main tooth of 1 st segment; inner lobe of 3 rd segment with 3 bristles, shorter bristle hirsute, other 2 with or 1 spine; outer lobe with 1 bare bristle and 1 (outer) with setules; 4 th plus 5 th segments united without peg; 4 th segment with 2–3 bristles, 5 th with 2 bristles; inner surface of these segments covered with long setules.

Sixth limb (Figs. 6 J; 8 D; 9 A). Epipodial appendage with 4 bristles ( 1–2 short), tiny process near base of proximal bristle and 2 proximal processes; 1 st endite with 6 bristles, 2 terminal and 4 medial; 2 nd endite with 5– 6 bristles, 2–3 terminal and 3 medial; 3 rd and 4 th endites each with 3 terminal bristles; end segment with 14 bristles, 2 posterior hirsute, others with long proximal setules, inner surface of all endites and end segment covered with setules.

Seventh limb (Fig. 8 E). Terminal comb with about 5 long recurved teeth with digitate tips; elongate curved peg present opposite comb; teeth and peg annulate. Limb with distal group contains 16 distal bristles ( 7 ventral and 9 dorsal, each with 3–5 bells) and proximal group with 12 bristles ( 6 ventral and 6 dorsal, each with 2-4 bells).

Furca
. Each lamella with 8 claws separated from lamella by suture; claws decrease in length posteriorly along lamella, each claw with teeth along posterior margin and with minute spines in row along anterior margin: a few minute spines present along anterior margin of each lamella.

Copulatory limbs (
Figs. 9
B–E). Each copulatory limb with 3 lobes. Finger-like lobe with 6–7 small teeth, shortest lobe with 12–13 bristles, longest lobe with stout recurved terminal process and with 4 proximal bristles.
Lateral eye . Eyes small, pigmented, with 4 ommatidia.
Medial eye (Fig. 5 A). Eye large and pigmented.
Bellonci organ (Fig. 5 A). Organ short and cylindrical.

Upper lip (Fig. 5 A). Anterior part large, unpaired and with terminal glandular processes. Paired tusks relatively short (somewhat less than height of anterior part) with few glandular processes. Bulge posterior to tusks hirsute.
Anterior body (Fig. 5 A). Straight and with very small anterior process; height subequal to height of anterior part of upper lip.

Comparisons . Male differs from female by smaller size and structure of infold of caudal siphon; by number, arming and size of bristles (and teeth on 5 th and 7 th limbs) on 1 st and 2 nd antennae, mandible and on 5 th, 6 th and 7 th limbs; also by shape and height of upper lip and anterior body (table 2 ).

Distribution . This species is known only from the Southern Ocean. It has been collected in the Atlantic Sector of this ocean between 48 ºS and 61 ºS and from the Pacific Sector in area 48 ºS– 148 ºE at the depth of 1790–1803 m (
Fig. 1
, table 1 ).
